categories.title: Position Papers
categories.description: These papers make really interesting arguments about human-AI interaction which I find compelling or at least useful to think about. (I don't necessarily agree with all the papers below.)

papers.title: We Can't Understand AI Using our Existing Vocabulary
papers.authors: John Hewitt, Robert Geirhos, Been Kim
papers.commentary: A compelling articulation of what human-AI communication could look like. Proposes neologism learning.

papers.title: Prompting as Scientific Inquiry
papers.authors: Ari Holtzman, Chenhao Tan
papers.commentary: Makes a really interesting case for disambiguating prompt 'engineering' from a possible 'prompt science'. The writing is very compelling. A helpful analogy presented in the paper is the idea that plant breeders were able to infer a lot of the internal structure of plants before genetic theory explained it. Not sure where I stand on this still but it's given me a lot to think about, especially w.r.t. 'aesthetic' concerns in ML research that bar 'prompting' from being seen as a legitimate research method. I do agree with the paper's claim that many important works in NLP are basically interfaces/structures upon prompting, and we shouldn't be afraid to more closely associate them with a 'prompt science'.

papers.title: AI Should Not Be An Imitation Game: Centaur Evaluations
papers.authors: Andreas Haupt, Erik Brynjolfsson
papers.commentary: Advocates and proposes directions for systematic AI evalutions involving real human interaction.

papers.title: AI Technologies are System Maps, and You are a Cartographer
papers.authors: Nicholas Vincent
papers.commentary: Explains the 'data as labor' perspective for AI via the compelling analogy of map economics.

papers.title: Toward cultural interpretability: A linguistic anthropological framework for describing and evaluating large language models
papers.authors: Graham M Jones, Shai Satran, Arvind Satyanarayan
papers.commentary: Advocates for understanding LLM behavior as indicative of nuances in human social behavior.

papers.title: HCI for AGI
papers.authors: Meredith Ringel Morris
papers.commentary: Useful outline of what HCI researchers can contribute to 'AGI'. It's not obvious (and people may fear that) interaction problems will be solved by AGI. Perhaps not?

papers.title: AI and the Demise of College Writing
papers.authors: Adam Walker
papers.commentary: Advocates for rhetoric over composition as the methodology for writing pedagogy in the AI era.

papers.title: Towards Bidirectional Human-AI Alignment: A Systematic Review for Clarifications, Framework, and Future Directions
papers.authors: Hua Shen, Tiffany Knearem, Reshmi Ghosh, Kenan Alkiek, Kundan Krishna, et al.
papers.commentary: A recognition that not only must AI 'align to' human (values, behavior, knowledge, etc.) (-- whatever this means), but we also need to think about how humans might 'align' to AI by working with AI-structured systems. This paper recognizes social 'looping effects' brought about by AI and its behavior.

papers.title: Large AI models are cultural and social technologies
papers.authors: Henry Farrell, Alison Gopnik, Cosma Shalizi, James Evans
papers.commentary: Argues for understanding LLMs as technologies that reconstitute human knowledge in efficient and widely distributed ways, in a lineage of other such instruments, including markets and communication media.

papers.title: Political Neutrality in AI Is Impossible- But Here Is How to Approximate It
papers.authors: Jillian Fisher, Ruth E. Appel, Chan Young Park, Yujin Potter, Liwei Jiang, et al.
papers.commentary: Makes what I think is an important point that there is no such thing as 'eliminating bias' in AI, and gives reasonable measures for how to proceed nevertheless in not building partisan hack LLMs. I personally find the 'Output Transparency', 'System Transaprency', and 'Neutrality Through Diversity' approximation techniques the most compelling. I appreciate what this paper does for broadening a notion of 'neutrality' in AI, drawing on the large existing body of political and philosophical work making the point.

categories.title: AI Tools for Human Knowledge
categories.description: These tools leverage the properties of AI to help us know more.

papers.title: Sparse Autoencoders for Hypothesis Generation
papers.authors: Rajiv Movva, Kenny Peng, Nikhil Garg, Jon Kleinberg, Emma Pierson
papers.commentary: This paper uses sparse autoencoder features to identify possible hypotheses to explain relationships between text and a dependent variable.

papers.title: Concept Induction: Analyzing Unstructured Text with High-Level Concepts Using LLooM
papers.authors: Michelle S. Lam, Janice Teoh, James Landay, Jeffrey Heer, Michael S. Bernstein
papers.commentary: This paper defines LLM operations for extracting concepts from large amounts of unstructured text, useful for social sciences inquiry.

papers.title: Bridging the Human-AI Knowledge Gap: Concept Discovery and Transfer in AlphaZero
papers.authors: Lisa Schut, Nenad Tomasev, Tom McGrath, Demis Hassabis, Ulrich Paquet, Been Kim
papers.commentary: The authors show how machine-unique/discovered chess-playing concepts can be extracted and taught to human chess-players.

categories.title: Concept-structured AI
categories.description: These approaches systematically build human-level concepts into the way AI models are designed, so we can understand and intervene.

papers.title: Jury Learning: Integrating Dissenting Voices into Machine Learning Models
papers.authors: Mitchell L. Gordon, Michelle S. Lam, Joon Sung Park, Kayur Patel, Jeffrey T. Hancock, Tatsunori Hashimoto, Michael S. Bernstein
papers.commentary: By modeling individual views rather than an aggregated 'view', we can explicitly define the voices 'heard' in making a decision and consider counterfactuals.

papers.title: Concept Bottleneck Models
papers.authors: Pang Wei Koh, Thao Nguyen, Yew Siang Tang, Stephen Mussmann, Emma Pierson, Been Kim, Percy Liang
papers.commentary: By learning explicitly defined concepts to bridge independent and dependent variables, we can better interpret model decisions and intervene on mistakes.

papers.title: Explaining Datasets in Words: Statistical Models with Natural Language Parameters
papers.authors: Ruiqi Zhong, Heng Wang, Dan Klein, Jacob Steinhardt
papers.commentary: Language modeling in terms of natural language predicates

papers.title: Large Concept Models: Language Modeling in a Sentence Representation Space
papers.authors: Loïc Barrault, Paul-Ambroise Duquenne, Maha Elbayad, Artyom Kozhevnikov, Belen Alastruey, et al.
papers.commentary: Language modeling operating in embedding rather than token space.

papers.title: Backpack Language Models
papers.authors: John Hewitt, John Thickstun, Christopher D. Manning, Percy Liang
papers.commentary: By creating an LM architecture in which input tokens have a direct log-linear effect on the output, we can intervene precisely on the model output.

categories.title: Interpretability
categories.description: Interesting works on understanding how complex models produce outputs and represent knowledge.

papers.title: Finding Neurons in a Haystack: Case Studies with Sparse Probing
papers.authors: Wes Gurnee, Neel Nanda, Matthew Pauly, Katherine Harvey, Dmitrii Troitskii, Dimitris Bertsimas
papers.commentary: By probing with sparsity constraints, we can identify not only if model activations represent some feature but whether specific neurons encode certain features.

papers.title: Discovering Latent Knowledge in Language Models Without Supervision
papers.authors: Collin Burns, Haotian Ye, Dan Klein, Jacob Steinhardt
papers.commentary: A method to probe structure in language models without any notion of ground truth, relying instead on the consistency property of tru statements.

papers.title: Language Models Use Trigonometry to Do Addition
papers.authors: Subhash Kantamneni, Max Tegmark
papers.commentary: The title is all you need to know! Super cool!

categories.title: Human-AI Interaction
categories.description: Interesting HCI-oriented work exploring how we can interact with AI or with other humans mediated by AI.

papers.title: Embedding Comparator: Visualizing Differences in Global Structure and Local Neighborhoods via Small Multiples
papers.authors: Angie Boggust, Brandon Carter, Arvind Satyanarayan
papers.commentary: A very useful interface for comparing differences in embeddings with interesting applications to model training development and the social sciences.

categories.title: Philosophy
categories.description: Smaller articles in contemporary-ish philosophy that I think are interesting or insightful.

papers.title: Why Isn’t There More Progress in Philosophy?
papers.authors: David J. Chalmers
papers.commentary: Asks an interesting question and gives some helpful directions to start thinking about what progress means in philosophy and how 'premise deniability' might be a relevant factor.

categories.title: Miscellaneous
categories.description: Interesting HCI-oriented work exploring how we can interact with AI or with other humans mediated by AI.

papers.title: The Economics of Maps
papers.authors: Abhishek Nagaraj, Scott Stern
papers.commentary: An interesting analysis of economic issues in who uses and produces maps.
